identification.introduction: Basic identification parameters and crystallographic information for HgCdTe.

notes: This CAS number represents the generic HgCdTe alloy. Specific compositions might have different identifiers or no specific CAS number.

key_characteristics: Alloy formed between Mercury Telluride (HgTe, a semimetal) and Cadmium Telluride (CdTe, a semiconductor).
Belongs to the II-VI group based on periodic table columns of constituents (Group 12: Hg, Cd; Group 16: Te).
Adopts the Zinc Blende structure, common for many III-V and II-VI semiconductors.
Features two interpenetrating Face-Centered Cubic (FCC) sublattices: one for cations (Hg/Cd mix), one for anions (Te).
Lacks inversion symmetry.
Non-centrosymmetric cubic space group associated with the Zinc Blende structure type.

lattice_constant.summary: Approx. 6.461 - 6.481 Å (at RT, near linear with x)

key_characteristics: Varies nearly linearly with Cadmium mole fraction (x) following Vegard's law.
a<sub>HgTe</sub> ≈ 6.461 Å
a<sub>CdTe</sub> ≈ 6.481 Å
Small variation allows lattice-matching to substrates like CdZnTe.

equations.name: Vegard's Law Approximation
equations.description: Linear interpolation for lattice constant (a) vs. composition (x).

device_relevance: Crucial for selecting lattice-matched substrates (minimizes defects).
Strain in mismatched layers affects band structure.

phase_diagram_notes.summary: Pseudo-binary; Narrow liquidus-solidus gap; Requires Hg overpressure

key_characteristics: Pseudo-binary HgTe-CdTe system with complete solid solubility.
Narrow liquidus-solidus gap complicates uniform bulk growth (segregation issues).
High Hg vapor pressure requires controlled Hg partial pressure during growth and annealing to prevent decomposition and control stoichiometry (V<sub>Hg</sub>).
significance: Favors epitaxial growth over bulk methods for uniformity.

appearance.summary: Dark gray / black solid with metallic luster

notes: Can vary slightly with surface finish and composition.
Thin films may show interference colors.

electrical_properties.introduction: Electrical characteristics govern HgCdTe's performance as an IR detector, primarily through its tunable bandgap and carrier transport properties. Precise control and understanding of these parameters are crucial for device design and optimization.

key_characteristics: Direct gap enables efficient absorption/emission near E_g.
Tunability via Cd mole fraction (x) allows targeting specific IR bands (SWIR/MWIR/LWIR).
device_relevance: Enables broad spectral range coverage with a single material system.

key_characteristics: Determines absorption cutoff wavelength (λ<sub>c</sub>) and intrinsic carrier concentration (n<sub>i</sub>).
Strong temperature dependence: Narrows significantly as temperature increases.
Composition (x) dependence is primary tuning mechanism (See Equations).

considerations: Accurate temperature control during measurement is essential due to strong E_g(T) dependence.

device_relevance: Governs intrinsic carrier concentration (n<sub>i</sub>), impacting dark current.
Primary parameter verified after growth to confirm composition.

equations.name: Hansen E_g(x,T) Empirical Relation
equations.description: Standard empirical fit for bandgap (eV) vs. Cd mole fraction (x) and temperature (T [K]). Widely used for device modeling. Valid for x < 0.6, T > 4.2K.

significance: Allows calculation of E_g for device modeling and prediction of optical properties.

common_dopants.summary: n-type: In, I; p-type: As, Au, V<sub>Hg</sub>

doping_methods: Native V<sub>Hg</sub> acceptors controlled via stoichiometry anneal.
key_characteristics: n: Group III (In) or VII (I).
p: Group V (As), IB (Au), or Hg Vacancies (V<sub>Hg</sub>).
V<sub>Hg</sub> control via anneal (Hg overpressure, T, time) is crucial.
Typical active levels: 10¹⁴ - 10¹⁶ cm⁻³.

carrier_concentration.summary: Low n_i at 77K; Extrinsic control via doping (10¹⁴-10¹⁶ cm⁻³ typical)

key_characteristics: Intrinsic n<sub>i</sub> highly sensitive to E<sub>g</sub> & T. Requires cryo-cooling for LWIR.
Extrinsic concentration set by net active dopant density.

equations.name: Intrinsic Carrier Conc. (n_i) Empirical Relation
equations.description: Approximate fit for n<sub>i</sub> (cm⁻³) vs. x and T [K].

equations.name: Carrier Conc. from Hall (Single Carrier)
equations.formula_html: n = -r<sub>H</sub> / (q R<sub>H</sub>)   or   p = r<sub>H</sub> / (q R<sub>H</sub>)

considerations: Hall: Bulk average, needs low T for n<sub>i</sub>.

device_relevance: Influences ρ, free carrier absorption, τ.

electron_mobility.summary: High (>10⁴ cm²/Vs @ 77K); Sensitive to T, x, Doping, Defects

key_characteristics: Governs electron drift velocity.
Limited by: Phonons (high T), Impurities (low T, high doping), Alloy scattering (depends on x), Defects.
Decreases with increasing T, doping, and usually x.
Small m*<sub>e</sub>(x) contributes to high mobility.

equations.name: Mobility from Hall Measurement
equations.description: Calculates Hall mobility (μ<sub>H</sub> = r<sub>H</sub>μ<sub>drift</sub>) from R<sub>H</sub> and resistivity (ρ).

key_characteristics: Lower than μ<sub>e</sub> due to larger hole effective mass (m*<sub>h</sub>).
Slight composition (x) and temperature dependence.
Strongly dependent on doping, T, x (via n<sub>i</sub>, μ).
Field initiating avalanche or tunneling.
Lower in narrow-gap (low x) HgCdTe.
Mechanisms: Avalanche, BTBT, TAT.
device_relevance: Tunneling often limits performance before avalanche.

optical_properties.introduction: Optical characteristics define how HgCdTe interacts with light, enabling its use as an infrared detector. Key properties include spectral range, absorption, and refractive index.

key_characteristics: Operation range defined by tunable bandgap E_g(x).
VLWIR: x < 0.18
device_relevance: Determines application space (thermal imaging, gas sensing, astronomy).
Requires precise composition control for targeted wavelength.

key_characteristics: Wavelength where photon energy equals bandgap (E_g), defining the long-wavelength absorption edge.
Primary specification parameter for IR detector material.

equations.name: Cutoff Wavelength from E_g(x,T)
equations.description: Calculates cutoff wavelength (μm) by substituting the Hansen E_g(x,T) relation into λ<sub>c</sub> ≈ 1.24 / E_g. Accurate determination of x and T is crucial.

considerations: Typically defined as wavelength where transmission drops to 50% of maximum.
Measurement temperature must match operating temperature due to E_g(T).

device_relevance: Directly sets the long-wavelength limit of detector sensitivity.

key_characteristics: High index leads to significant Fresnel reflection (~30%) at air interface.
Exhibits dispersion (varies with wavelength).
Slight dependence on composition (x) and temperature.
device_relevance: Requires Anti-Reflection (AR) coatings for efficient light coupling.

key_characteristics: Strong absorption above E_g due to direct bandgap.
α increases sharply with photon energy.
Allows high absorption efficiency in thin layers (few μm).
Ratio of collected carriers to incident photons.
Internal QE (IQE) >90% possible.
External QE (EQE) limited by reflection & IQE.
Affected by surface recombination, τ, L.

equations.name: QE from Responsivity
equations.description: Relates QE to measured spectral responsivity R(λ).

techniques: Spectral response measurement vs. calibrated reference.

device_relevance: Requires AR coating & good material quality to maximize.

key_characteristics: Photocurrent per incident power (I<sub>ph</sub> / P<sub>inc</sub>).
Proportional to QE and wavelength.

techniques: Measure photocurrent vs. calibrated source power.

device_relevance: Determines electrical signal output for given optical input.

key_characteristics: Incident power giving SNR=1 in 1 Hz bandwidth.
Lower NEP = better sensitivity.
Limited by detector noise sources.

equations.name: NEP Definition
equations.description: Relates NEP to noise current (i<sub>n</sub>) and responsivity (R).

thermal_properties.introduction: Thermal characteristics influence operating temperature requirements, cooling needs, and thermal stability.

mechanical_properties.introduction: HgCdTe is a relatively soft and brittle semiconductor, requiring careful handling during processing and integration.
